body:
### Problem

When passing mixed paths to `grepprg`, `makeprg`, or `shellpipe` on Windows, they put everything after the first `/` into the arguments. However, everything before the first whitespace should be considered part of the program name.

`shellslash` doesn't help.

Windows does not allow forward slashes in file or folder names, so they should be considered path separators. [CreateFile docs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/fileapi/nf-fileapi-createfilea#parameters):

> The name of the file or device to be created or opened. You may use either forward slashes (/) or backslashes (\) in this name.

[Naming Conventions docs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/naming-a-file#naming-conventions):
> The following reserved characters:
```
< (less than)
> (greater than)
: (colon)
" (double quote)
/ (forward slash)
\ (backslash)
| (vertical bar or pipe)
? (question mark)
* (asterisk)
```



Also reproducible on nvim-win64-0.10.4.

### Steps to reproduce



#### Error case

```vim
set makeprg=C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin/find
let &shellpipe = '| %USERPROFILE%\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin\tee'
cd %:h
make . -name README.md
copen
```
nvim.exe -Nu ~/minimal.vim -U NONE c:\code\public-clones\neovim\CONTRIBUTING.md

Output (_copied from screenshot_):
```
:!C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin/find . -name README.md | tee C:\Users\idbrii\AppData\Local\Temp\nvim.0\gmwA7X\1
'C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file.

shell returned 255
```
(`s/make/grep/g` and you get the same result.)

Windows is fine with this command. Directly running it correctly outputs a list of READMEs:
```
:!C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin/find . -name README.md
```


A more practical example is to use your home directory in prg paths (which should work on both Unix and Windows):
```
set grepprg=~/.vim/scripts/supergrep
```
nvim expands `~` using backslashes so we have mixed slashes:
```
'C:\Users\idbrii' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file.
```

Here, `shellslash` *does* have an effect. The resulting path uses only forward slashes but nvim still assumes only backslashes can be part of the name:
```
'C:' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file.
```

`shellpipe` similarly doesn't allow forward slashes.
```
set grepprg=C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin/find
let &shellpipe = '| %USERPROFILE%/scoop/apps/git/current/usr/bin/tee'
cd %:h
grep . -name README.md
copen
```

#### Argument test

I tested my assumption that prg handling is ending the path at the first `/`:

```vim
set grepprg=C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin\echo.exe/test
let &shellpipe = '| %USERPROFILE%\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin\tee'
cd %:h
grep . -name README.md
copen
```

This command succeeds, but the quickfix output shows that `/test` is considered one of the arguments instead of part of the file path:
```
|| /test . -name README.md
```




### Expected behavior

Everything before the first unescaped whitespace should be considered part of the program name.

If we change `/find` -> `\find`, then it correctly finds all the README.md files. We shouldn't have to change all our paths to use backslashes. They might come from a variety of places: plugins, environment variables, program output (`where`), etc.

Additionally, the above minimal vimrc files work correctly on vim, plugins that work on vim will break on nvim. Example: [tpope/vim-eunuch](https://github.com/tpope/vim-eunuch)'s `:Cfind` command.


### Nvim version (nvim -v)

v0.11.5

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no, vim 9.0.1576

### Operating system/version

Win11 (Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.26200.7462])

### Terminal name/version

Command Prompt

### $TERM environment variable

not set

### Installation

scoop

comment_data.body: Hi! I can reproduce this on Windows and would like to look into fixing it. Any guidance would help, thanks!

From what I understand, on Windows both \ and / are valid path separators.
the issue seems to happen because Neovim parses the command string first, and / is treated as special even when it’s part of a path.
maybe normalizing paths (or escaping them) before this parsing step would avoid the mixed-slash case, instead of trying to detect it later.

would this be a right approach @idbrii?

> the issue seems to happen because Neovim parses the command string first, and / is treated as special even when it’s part of a path.

Source?

> `: !C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin/find . -name README.md | tee C:\Users\idbrii\AppData\Local\Temp\nvim.0\gmwA7X\1`

Are you sure this is the output of `:make`? There shouldn't be a space between `:` and `!` in that case.

> Windows is fine with this command. Directly running it correctly outputs a list of READMEs

What does "this command" refer to? Did you try running `C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin/find . -name README.md | tee somefile` directly in cmd.exe?

>Are you sure this is the output of :make? There shouldn't be a space between : and ! in that case.

I couldn't easily copy that text so I took a screenshot and used OCR to copy it. That space is a mistake. Fixed.

> What does "this command" refer to? 

The next line (run from inside nvim): 
```
:!C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin/find . -name README.md
```
Running `C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin/find . -name README.md` in cmd.exe also works fine.

**However**, I didn't try running with `tee` and that does make a difference! Once you add a pipe, it stops working:
```
C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin/find . -name README.md | C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin\tee junkfile

'C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file.
```
_Side note: running this command directly in powershell works. Not sure about `shell=pwsh`._

But if you quote it, then it works:
```
"C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin/find" . -name README.md | "C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin/tee" junkfile
./.deps/build/src/libuv/README.md
...
```

It looks like the behaviour is different between vim and neovim because they have different default values for `shellpipe`:

vim: 

    shellpipe=>%s 2>&1

nvim:


    shellpipe=2>&1| tee

Using nvim's shellpipe in vim causes it to also fail with error 255 and quoting it fixes it.

Quoting the path in makeprg is awkward, but it also works:
`set makeprg=\"C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin/find\"`. Probably better to pass it through expand: `let &makeprg = expand("C:\Users\idbrii\scoop\apps\git\current\usr\bin/find")`

@chahat-101: Can you confirm that using `let &shellpipe = ">%s 2>&1"` prevents this error for you too? (Obviously, losing tee isn't ideal. But to make sure I'm not missing something.)

title: grepprg,makeprg,shellslash don't handle mixed slashes in path
